title: Can a creditor recover from a revocable trust if the debtor is a beneficiary?
question: If I am the beneficiary of a revocable trust, but have not received any disbursements because the family member who created the trust (the settlor) is still alive, can a creditor who has a judgment against me recover from the trust in some way? If I discharge the debt in chapter 7 bankruptcy before the settlor dies, can I then keep all the money or other property that the trust entitles me to after the settlor dies?
answers:
Excellent responses from colleagues. I agree and add:
Properly drafted revocable trust may protect beneficiary interest from creditors. Poorly drafted trust will not.
Beneficiary entitled to nothing until settlor dies, you survive whatever survival period is in the trust.
Some trusts allow trustee to distribute money to you free of creditor claims. Other language would have the trustee not send you any money until after your financial problems are cleared up.
Even with a spendthrift clause cetain trusts allow a creditor can get 25% of what. ever is to be distributed to you.
If you become entitled to an inheritance before the bankruptcy or within 180 days after discharge you must inform bankruptcy trustee. The trustee may claim your interest and use it to pay your creditors..
Very good advice and a good statement of trust law from my colleagues.

1. You are entitled to nothing until the settlor dies AND you survive whatever survival period is in the trust. Also, some trusts would have the trustee not send you any money until after your financial problems are cleared up.
2. Even with a spendthrift clause, a creditor can get 25% of what. ever is to be distributed to you.
3. If you become entitled to an inheritance before the bankruptcy. or within 180 days after, you have to inform the bankruptcy trustee. The trustee will use the. funds to pay your creditors.

Maybe. When a person prepares a trust and knows that some of his beneficiaries may have trouble with creditors, a "spendthrift clause" can be included. A trust with a spendthrift clause is an ideal estate planning tool in situations where a beneficiary has demonstrated an inability to handle money responsibly for any reason. However, each spendthrift clause must be carefully drafted to accommodate the circumstances. Such clauses are valid in the US and even some foreign countries.
